net.opentsdb.utils

Class DateTime

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.opentsdb.utils.DateTime

  • public class DateTime
extends Object
    Utility class that provides helpers for dealing with dates and timestamps. In particular, this class handles parsing relative or human readable date/time strings provided in queries.
    Since:
    2.0

    • Field Detail

      • UTC_ID

        public static final String UTC_ID
        ID of the UTC timezone
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • timezones

        public static final HashMap<String,TimeZone> timezones
        Immutable cache mapping a timezone name to its object. We do this because the JDK's TimeZone class was implemented by retards, and it's synchronized, going through a huge pile of code, and allocating new objects all the time. And to make things even better, if you ask for a TimeZone that doesn't exist, it returns GMT! It is thus impractical to tell if the timezone name was valid or not. JDK_brain_damage++; Note: caching everything wastes a few KB on RAM (34KB on my system with 611 timezones -- each instance is 56 bytes with the Sun JDK).

    • Constructor Detail

      • DateTime

        public DateTime()

    • Method Detail

      • parseDateTimeString

        public static final long parseDateTimeString(String datetime,
                                             String tz)
        Attempts to parse a timestamp from a given string Formats accepted are:
        • Relative: 5m-ago, 1h-ago, etc. See parseDuration(java.lang.String)
        • Absolute human readable dates:
          • "yyyy/MM/dd-HH:mm:ss"
          • "yyyy/MM/dd HH:mm:ss"
          • "yyyy/MM/dd-HH:mm"
          • "yyyy/MM/dd HH:mm"
          • "yyyy/MM/dd"
        • Unix Timestamp in seconds or milliseconds:
          • 1355961600
          • 1355961600000
          • 1355961600.000
        Parameters:
        datetime - The string to parse a value for
        tz - The timezone to use for parsing.
        Returns:
        A Unix epoch timestamp in milliseconds
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the timestamp is null
        IllegalArgumentException - if the request was malformed

      • parseDuration

        public static final long parseDuration(String duration)
        Parses a human-readable duration (e.g, "10m", "3h", "14d") into seconds.

        Formats supported:

        • ms: milliseconds
        • s: seconds
        • m: minutes
        • h: hours
        • d: days
        • w: weeks
        • n: month (30 days)
        • y: years (365 days)
        Parameters:
        duration - The human-readable duration to parse.
        Returns:
        A strictly positive number of milliseconds.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the interval was malformed.

      • getDurationUnits

        public static final String getDurationUnits(String duration)
        Returns the suffix or "units" of the duration as a string. The result will be ms, s, m, h, d, w, n or y.
        Parameters:
        duration - The duration in the format #units, e.g. 1d or 6h
        Returns:
        Just the suffix, e.g. 'd' or 'h'
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the duration is null, empty or if the units are invalid.
        Since:
        2.4

      • getDurationInterval

        public static final int getDurationInterval(String duration)
        Parses the prefix of the duration, the interval and returns it as a number. E.g. if you supply "1d" it will return "1". If you supply "60m" it will return "60".
        Parameters:
        duration - The duration to parse in the format #units, e.g. "1d" or "60m"
        Returns:
        The interval as an integer, regardless of units.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the duration is null, empty or parsing of the integer failed.
        Since:
        2.4

      • isRelativeDate

        public static boolean isRelativeDate(String value)
        Returns whether or not a date is specified in a relative fashion.

        A date is specified in a relative fashion if it ends in "-ago", e.g. 1d-ago is the same as 24h-ago.

        Parameters:
        value - The value to parse
        Returns:
        true if the parameter is passed and is a relative date. Note the method doesn't attempt to validate the relative date. So this function can return true on something that looks like a relative date, but is actually invalid once we really try to parse it.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the value is null

      • setTimeZone

        public static void setTimeZone(SimpleDateFormat fmt,
                               String tzname)
        Applies the given timezone to the given date format.
        Parameters:
        fmt - Date format to apply the timezone to.
        tzname - Name of the timezone, or null in which case this function is a no-op.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if tzname isn't a valid timezone name.
        NullPointerException - if the format is null

      • setDefaultTimezone

        public static void setDefaultTimezone(String tzname)
        Sets the default timezone for this running OpenTSDB instance

        WARNING If OpenTSDB is used with a Security Manager, setting the default timezone only works for the running thread. Otherwise it will work for the entire application.

        Parameters:
        tzname - Name of the timezone to use
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if tzname isn't a valid timezone name

      • currentTimeMillis

        public static long currentTimeMillis()
        Pass through to System.currentTimeMillis() for use in classes to make unit testing easier. Mocking System.class is a bad idea in general so placing this here and mocking DateTime.class is MUCH cleaner.
        Returns:
        The current epoch time in milliseconds
        Since:
        2.1

      • nanoTime

        public static long nanoTime()
        Pass through to System.nanoTime() for use in classes to make unit testing easier. Mocking System.class is a bad idea in general so placing this here and mocking DateTime.class is MUCH cleaner.
        Returns:
        The current epoch time in milliseconds
        Since:
        2.2

      • msFromNano

        public static double msFromNano(long ts)
        Converts the long nanosecond value to a double in milliseconds
        Parameters:
        ts - The timestamp or value in nanoseconds
        Returns:
        The timestamp in milliseconds
        Since:
        2.2

      • msFromNanoDiff

        public static double msFromNanoDiff(long end,
                                    long start)
        Calculates the difference between two values and returns the time in milliseconds as a double.
        Parameters:
        end - The end timestamp
        start - The start timestamp
        Returns:
        The value in milliseconds
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if end is less than start
        Since:
        2.2

      • previousInterval

        public static Calendar previousInterval(long ts,
                                        int interval,
                                        int unit)
        Returns a calendar set to the previous interval time based on the units and UTC the timezone. This allows for snapping to day, week, monthly, etc. boundaries. NOTE: It uses a calendar for snapping so isn't as efficient as a simple modulo calculation. NOTE: For intervals that don't nicely divide into their given unit (e.g. a 23s interval where 60 seconds is not divisible by 23) the base time may start at the top of the day (for ms and s) or from Unix epoch 0. In the latter case, setting up the base timestamp may be slow if the caller does something silly like "23m" where we iterate 23 minutes at a time from 0 till we find the proper timestamp. TODO - There is likely a better way to do all of this
        Parameters:
        ts - The timestamp to find an interval for, in milliseconds as a Unix epoch.
        interval - The interval as a measure of units.
        unit - The unit. This must cast to a Calendar time unit.
        Returns:
        A calendar set to the timestamp aligned to the proper interval before the given ts
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the timestamp is negative, if the interval is less than 1 or the unit is unrecognized.
        Since:
        2.3

      • previousInterval

        public static Calendar previousInterval(long ts,
                                        int interval,
                                        int unit,
                                        TimeZone tz)
        Returns a calendar set to the previous interval time based on the units and timezone. This allows for snapping to day, week, monthly, etc. boundaries. NOTE: It uses a calendar for snapping so isn't as efficient as a simple modulo calculation. NOTE: For intervals that don't nicely divide into their given unit (e.g. a 23s interval where 60 seconds is not divisible by 23) the base time may start at the top of the day (for ms and s) or from Unix epoch 0. In the latter case, setting up the base timestamp may be slow if the caller does something silly like "23m" where we iterate 23 minutes at a time from 0 till we find the proper timestamp. TODO - There is likely a better way to do all of this
        Parameters:
        ts - The timestamp to find an interval for, in milliseconds as a Unix epoch.
        interval - The interval as a measure of units.
        unit - The unit. This must cast to a Calendar time unit.
        tz - An optional timezone.
        Returns:
        A calendar set to the timestamp aligned to the proper interval before the given ts
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the timestamp is negative, if the interval is less than 1 or the unit is unrecognized.
        Since:
        2.3

      • unitsToCalendarType

        public static int unitsToCalendarType(String units)
        Return the proper Calendar time unit as an integer given the string
        Parameters:
        units - The unit to parse
        Returns:
        An integer matching a Calendar.<UNIT> enum
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - if the unit is null, empty or doesn't match one of the configured units.
        Since:
        2.3
